case_data.name: Foster v. City of Oakland
case_data.plaintiff_description: Men who claimed they were wrongfully searched by Oakland Police
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On August 1, 2005, a group of men, who claimed they were wrongfully searched, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs sued the City of Oakland, the Oakland Chief of Police, and Oakland police officers under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, alleged that the defendants violated the plaintiffsโ constitutional rights through a policy and practice of performing strip searches and body-cavity searches in public on only โreasonable suspicionโ that people were hiding something illegal. The plaintiffs sought both injunctive relief and damages. This case was related to eight similar cases pending in the Northern District of California.

On September 20, 2005, the plaintiffs filed their first amended complaint for class action and individual relief for injuries and violation of their civil rights. On October 6, 2005 the case was reassigned to Judge Marilyn Hall Patel. Discovery proceeded for 18 months. On January 29, 2007, Judge Patel denied the plaintiffsโ motion for class certification. 2007 WL 219796.

The parties each moved for summary judgment, and the individual defendants sought qualified immunity (immunity from liability for a public official who is performing a discretionary function, as long as the conduct does not violate clearly established constitutional or statutory rights). On March 27, 2008, Judge Patel granted in part the plaintiffsโ motion for partial summary judgment. Judge Patel issued a declaratory judgment that the Oakland Police Departmentโs (โOPDโ) policies were unconstitutional in certain respects. Judge Patel denied the plaintiffsโ motion for summary judgment on liability and declaratory relief for the individual searches at issue. The strip-search policy was held unconstitutional because it provided too low a threshold for officers seeking to check for contraband on suspects in public places. The Court held that while reasonable suspicion is adequate to justify a strip search in the context of a detention facility when institutional security is a concern, it is โinsufficient to justify a strip search in the field.โ The police policy was held unconstitutional to the extent that it allowed strip searches of any kind in the field to be performed on less than probable cause. Judge Patel also found that an earlier version of the policy, enacted in 1998, was unconstitutional because it did not require that more invasive body-cavity searches be conducted by medical personnel. 621 F.Supp.2d 779 (N.D. Cal. 2008).

Litigation continued regarding the plaintiffsโ claims for liability and declaratory relief on the individual searches at issue. The plaintiffs renewed their motion for class certification, but on January 13, 2009, Judge Patel again denied the plaintiffsโ motion for class certification. 2009 WL 88433.

On December 14, 2009, Judge Patel granted in part an individual plaintiffโs motion for partial summary judgment on his Fourth Amendment claim for the unlawful strip search that a defendant officer conducted on the plaintiff. Judge Patel declined to rule on the issues of qualified immunity and damages because factual disputes needed to be resolved first. 675 F.Supp.2d 992 (N.D. Cal. 2009).

The officer petitioned the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals for a writ of mandamus ordering the district court to rule on the issue of qualified immunity. On January 13, 2010, the Ninth Circuit denied the defendantโs petition because there were still material questions of fact regarding qualified immunity, and the defendant had not asked the district court to rule on qualified immunity either by filing a motion for summary judgment or at trial.

On March 3, 2010, Judge Patel found that two of the cases were related to each other (C-08-4255MHP and C-04-4843MHP), but the other claims had been misjoined. Judge Patel gave the plaintiffs in those actions twenty days to drop all but one of the plaintiffs in each of the actions and to file new actions for each of the dropped plaintiffs. On December 1, 2011 the case was reassigned to Judge Susan Illston. Discovery and settlement negotiations proceeded for the next two years.

On April 18, 2013, the parties agreed to a settlement of injunctive and declaratory relief claims. The City of Oakland through the OPD agreed to institute a new policy concerning strip searches in the field. The OPD was required to capture and retain all complaints about strip searches conducted in the field and all reports of such searches for a period of two years from the entry of the order. Those reports were forwarded to the plaintiffโs counsel every six months, and the court maintained jurisdiction to ensure compliance for the two years. In the absence of any further proceedings, these related matters were fully and finally dismissed with prejudice on April 18, 2015. The case is closed.
case_data.summary_short: On August 1, 2005, a group of men, who claimed they were wrongfully strip searched, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 against the City of Oakland, the Oakland Chief of Police, and Oakland police officers. On April 18, 2013, the parties agreed to a settlement of injunctive and declaratory relief claims requiring the defendants to institute a new policy limiting strip searches in the field.

SSS ririri Plaintiffs Darnell Foster, Rafael Duarte, and Yancie Young have brought a putative class
DDDIII DistDistDist 16
ES ES ES  n n n  action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. section 1983 against the City of Oakland (โOaklandโ); Richard Word,
TTT ererer 17
AAA hhh
TTT rtrtrt individually and in his capacity as the Oakland Chief of Police; Oakland police officers J. Festag,
SSSooo
D D D  NNN 18

hhh
UUUNITNITNIT For tFor tFor t 19 alleging that defendants violated plaintiffsโ constitutional rights through a policy and practice of
20
performing strip searches and body-cavity searches in public.  Plaintiffs seek certification of three
21
subclasses: 1)  individuals subjected to a strip search and/or visual body-cavity search in public by
22
Oakland Police officers from August 1, 2003 to present and until this matter is adjudicated; 2)
23
individuals subjected to a physical body-cavity search in public by Oakland Police officers from

August 1, 2003 to present and until this matter is adjudicated; 3) individuals, based in part on their

So Officer Festag then guided Foster into the rear of the patrol vehicle.  The officers ran a warrant

evidence of wrongdoing.

Plaintiff Duarte is an Hispanic-American man.  On the afternoon of March 9, 2005, Duarte

27

3
C. Plaintiff Yancie Young
4
Plaintiff Young is an African-American man.  At approximately 11:30 p.m. on September
5
30, 2003, Young was pulled over by Officer Bergeron around the 2800 block of West Street in
6
Oakland.  Officer Bergeron opened Youngโs car door, pulled him out of the car, and handcuffed
7
him.  Officer Bergeron asked Young if he was on probation or parole, which Young denied   Officer
8
Bergeron insisted that he smelled marijuana in Youngโs car and suggested that Young was

Officer Bergeron then took Young to the back of a police car.  While facing Young, he

T a

O o
f

C f 
I o shoes and feeling Youngโs private area through his pants.  Another officer searched Youngโs car
R t  15
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 during the search of Youngโs person.  No contraband was found.  
TES  ern  17 Officer Bergeron seated Young in the back of a police car, still handcuffed, where he sat for
A h
T rt
So over one hour.  During that time, Officer Bergeron, other officers, and a police canine searched
D  N 18
E e 
NIT or th 19 Youngโs car.  That search produced no evidence of criminal activity.

No charges were filed against Young.  Young subsequently filed a complaint with the
20

D. Defendants
24
Defendant City of Oakland is a municipal corporation, operating the Oakland Police
25
Department and employing the additional defendants named below.  Defendant Richard Word is

3
  1. Oakland Police Departmentโs Policy Before 2004.
4
The Oakland Police Departmentโs 1998 policy, entitled โStrip Searches, Visual Body-Cavity
5
Searches, and Physical Body-Cavity Searches,โ barred such searches in public, unless there was an
6

Certification at 11. According to Captain Israel, who wrote that policy and trained fellow officers in
8

9
โurgent need.โ  Israel Dep., Pls.โ Exh. E at 28:11-29:14.  Captain Israel stated that examples of an
10
โurgent needโ to perform such searches included the possibilities of the suspect concealing a weapon

or some contraband that might be ingested or forced into the rectum.  Id. at 30:2-30:10.  The policy
12
T a
UR rni 13 did not require reasonable suspicion or probable cause.  Id. at 31:3-31:9.  There was also no
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 consideration as to the types of charges for which the suspect was being arrested.  Id. at 31:15-31:18.
C f 
I o 2. Oakland Police Departmentโs Amended Policy.
R t  15
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 In 2004, the Oakland Police Department amended its policy on strip and body-cavity
TES  ern  17 searches.  The amendments came in response to public concerns regarding the Departmentโs practice
A h
T rt
So of carrying out such searches.  The Department publicly identified a โlong-standing and problematic
D  N 18
E e 
NIT or th 19 practice of conducting strip searches in the field.โ  Pls.โ Exh. C at 4.  
UF
The revised policy added requirements for reasonable suspicion that the subject is concealing
20
a weapon or contraband.  Additionally, the revised policy addressed the subjectโs privacy, stating
21

3. Oakland Police Departmentโs Alleged Practice.

Plaintiffs allege that there is a widespread practice of public strip and body-cavity searches

28
5

Plaintiffs claim that this practice occurs without regard to the privacy of subjects being searched. 
1
Subjects genitalia, buttocks, and/or anuses are exposed, often without any screen from public view.

3
4
II. Procedural History
5
Plaintiffs Foster and Duarte filed the present action on August 1, 2005.  Pursuant to
6
stipulations, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on September 22, 2005 adding plaintiff Young.

Additionally, the following actions were related to this action: (1) Rider v. City of Oakland, No. C
8
05-3204 MHP, related on October 6, 2005; (2) Taylor v. City of Oakland, No. C 04-4843 MHP,
9
related on October 6, 2005; (3) Moore v. City of Oakland, No. C 06-02426 MHP, related on July 12,

2006.     
11
On behalf of themselves and a group of similarly-situated persons, plaintiffs charge that
12
T a
UR rni 13 defendants have a pattern and practice of public body-cavity searches, violating plaintiffsโ
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 constitutionally guaranteed rights including due process, freedom from unreasonable searches and
C f 
I o seizures, freedom from excessive use of forces by police officers, equal protection of the laws, and

T c

A h
T rt
So LEGAL STANDARD
D  N 18
E e 
NIT or th 19 A party seeking to certify a class must satisfy the four prerequisites enumerated in Rule
UF
23(a), as well as at least one of the requirements of Rule 23(b).  Under Rule 23(a), the party seeking
20
class certification must establish: (1) that the class is so large that joinder of all members is
21
impracticable (i.e., numerosity); (2) that there are one or more questions of law or fact common to
22
the class (i.e., commonality); (3) that the named partiesโ claims are typical of the class (i.e.,
23
typicality); and (4) that the class representatives will fairly and adequately protect the interests of
24
other members of the class (i.e., adequacy of representation).  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a).  In addition to
25
satisfying these prerequisites, parties seeking class certification must show that the action is
26
maintainable under Rule 23(b)(1), (2) or (3).  See Rule 23(b); Amchem Products, Inc. v. Windsor,
27
28
6

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document42    Filed01/29/07   Page7 of 10
521 U.S. 591, 614 (1997).  Rule 23(b)(2) permits class actions for declaratory or injunctive relief
1
where the party opposing the class โhas acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable to
2
the class.โ Rule 23(b)(2). 
3
The party seeking class certification bears the burden of establishing that the requirements of
4
Rules 23(a) and 23(b) have been met.  See Zinser v. Accufix Research Inst., Inc., 253 F.3d 1180,
5
1188 (9th Cir.  2001), amended by 273 F.3d 1266 (9th Cir. 2001); Hanon v. Dataproducts Corp., 976
6
F.2d 497, 508 (9th Cir. 1992).  However, in adjudicating a motion for class certification, the court
7
accepts the allegations in the complaint as true so long as those allegations are sufficiently specific
8
to permit an informed assessment as to whether the requirements of Rule 23 have been satisfied. 
9
See Blackie v. Barrack, 524 F.2d 891, 901 n.17 (9th Cir. 1975), cert. denied, 429 U.S. 816 (1976).  
10
The merits of the class membersโ substantive claims are generally irrelevant to this inquiry.  Eisen v.
11
Carlisle & Jacquelin, 417 U.S. 156, 177โ78 (1974); Moore v. Hughes Helicopters, Inc., 708 F.2d
12
T a
UR rni 13 475, 480 (9th Cir. 1983).
O o
f
CT  Cali 14
C f 
I o DISCUSSION
R t  15
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 Plaintiffs seek certification of three subclasses:  1) individuals subjected to a strip search
TES  ern  17 and/or visual body-cavity search in public by Oakland Police officers from August 1, 2003 to
A h
T rt
So present and until this matter is adjudicated; 2) individuals subjected to a physical body-cavity search
D  N 18
E e 
NIT or th 19 in public by Oakland Police officers from August 1, 2003 to present and until this matter is
UF
adjudicated; 3) individuals, based in part on their race and/or national origin, subjected to a strip
20
search, visual or physical body-cavity search in public by Oakland Police officers from August 1,
21
2003 to the present and until this matter is adjudicated.  They ask the court to certify their claims for
22
damages as well as injunctive relief under Rule 23(b)(1) and 23(b)(2). 
23
24
25
26
27
28
7

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document42    Filed01/29/07   Page8 of 10
Pursuant to Rule 23, the class must be โso numerous that joinder of all members is
1
impracticable.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1).  As a general rule, classes numbering greater than forty-
2
one individuals satisfy the numerosity requirement.  See 5 James Wm. Moore et al., Mooreโs Federal
3
Practice ยง 23.22[1][b] (3d ed. 2004).  Although plaintiffs need not allege the exact number or
4
identity of class members to satisfy the numerosity prerequisite, mere speculation as to the number
5
of parties involved is not sufficient to satisfy the numerosity requirement.  See Freedman v.
6
Louisiana-Pac. Corp., 922 F. Supp. 377, 398 (D. Or. 1996); 7 Wright, Miller, & Kane, Federal
7
Practice and Procedure ยง 1762 (3d ed. 1995).  Here, plaintiffs have identified sixteen potential class
8
members who were subject to either a public strip search and/or a public body-cavity search.  Nine
9
plaintiffs in this case and related cases have filed suit based on the alleged practice of public strip
10
and body-cavity searches by the Oakland Police Department; one case has been dismissed.  Seven
11
additional potential class members have been disclosed in the production of Internal Affairs
12
T a
UR rni 13 complaints filed by alleged subjects of public strip searches.  Word Dep. at 8:10โ10: 10.  As
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 defendants note, one of the putative class members, James Taylor, filed suit based on a search that
C f 
I o occurred on November 13, 2002, one year prior to the dates in the class definition.  According to this
R t  15
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 tally, plaintiffs have presented evidence of a sixteen alleged victims that meet the class definition. 
TES  ern  17 They further speculate that more potential class members are likely to be uncovered but provide no
A h
T rt
So evidence as to how many more class members there may be.  
D  N 18
E e 
NIT or th 19 While there is no specific numerical requirement in the text of Rule 23, courts have
UF
repeatedly held that classes of less than twenty members do not satisfy the numerosity requirement. 
20
See, e.g., General Tel. Co. of the Northwest, Inc. v.  EEOC, 446 U.S. 318, 330 & n.14 (1980)
21
(citing, with approval, cases in which numerosity was not met with as many as forty class members);
22
Harik v.  Cal.  Teacherโs Assโn, 326 F.3d 1042, 1052 (9th Cir. 2003) (vacating certification of
23
classes with less than ten members).  Plaintiffs have produced no evidence that the size of the
24
potential class is larger than fifteen members.  The text of Rule 23(a)(1) instructs the court to certify
25
a class only where joinder of all of the potential plaintiffs would be impracticable.  In this case,
26
joinder seems viable: all potential plaintiffs are in the same geographic area, and the small number
27
28
8

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document42    Filed01/29/07   Page9 of 10
of potential class members suggests that doing so would not be unduly burdensome.  Accordingly,
1
the court finds that plaintiffs have not satisfied the numerosity requirement at this time.  
2
Therefore, the court DENIES plaintiffsโ motion for class certification without prejudice to
3
their filing another such motion at a later time if plaintiffs can present evidence of a sufficiently
4
large number of potential class members. 
5
6
CONCLUSION
7
Based upon the foregoing, plaintiffsโ motion to certify a class is DENIED. 
8
9
IT IS SO ORDERED.

STATEMENT OF FACTS
19
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS REGARDING PLAINTIFF DARNELL FOSTER
20
13. On February 27, 2004, at around 3 p.m., Defendant Officer FESTAG stopped Plaintiff
21
FOSTER in front of a small market, the โSchool Marketโ, located near the corner of School Street
22
and Pleitner Avenue in Oakland, Caifornia.
23
14. Plaintiff FOSTER lived in Carson City, Nevada at the time, but was visiting friends
24
who lived in Oakland.  Plaintiff FOSTER had purchased two Black and Mild cigars at the School
25
Market shortly before Defendant Officer FESTAG and one other unknown Oakland Police Officer
26
DOE stopped him.  He possessed no contraband and was not engaged in any illegal activity
27
whatsoever.  Defendant Officers stopped Plaintiff FOSTER as he walked out of the School Market
28
and asked him for his identification.   Plaintiff FOSTER showed the officer his identification.  The
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR CLASS ACTION AND INDIVIDUAL RELIEF FOR INJURIES AND VIOLATION OF
CIVIL RIGHTS 3

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document6   Filed09/22/05   Page4 of 18
1 officers then asked him whether he was on probation or parole.  Plaintiff FOSTER honestly replied
2 that he was on probation. In fact, Plaintiff FOSTER,  only two months remained of the five year
3 felony unsupervised probation sentence for possession for sale of marijuana. Plaintiff FOSTER had
4 served his probation sentence without incurring  a single violation.  Plaintiff FOSTER told Defendant
5 Officer FESTAG that he had only two months remaining on his probation.
6 15. Defendant Officer FESTAG handcuffed Plaintiff FOSTER without explanation and
7 escorted him to the back of his patrol vehicle, which was parked in front of the School Market.
8 Defendant Officer FESTAG forced Plaintiff FOSTER against the back of the patrol vehicle and
9 ordered him to spread his legs.  Defendant Officer FESTAG searched Plaintiff FOSTERโs pockets
10 and found $22.  Defendant Officer FESTAG told Plaintiff FOSTER that the $22 would be

OFFICE OF CHIEF OF POLICE 
OAKLAND POLICE DEPARTMENT 
MEMORAND UM  
TO:  All Personnel   DATE: 02 Apr 13  
SUBJECT:  Revision of Departmental Training Bulletin I-O.02,
LEGAL ASPECTS OF SEARCHING PERSONS (Rev. 05 Oct 10).
The subject order has been revised to update Departmental policy and procedures regarding 
The Legal Aspects of Searching Persons.
Provisions of this Training Bulletin have been revised to include the following Departmental 
publications which are hereby canceled: 
โข  Information Bulletin 24 Apr 06 - Searches during a detention (patdown/Frisks);
โข  Information Bulletin 23 Dec 08 -Searches during a detention ;
โข  Special Order 8982 - Legal standard to conduct strip searches in the field (amended
to reflect current language in the TB); and 
โข  Training Bulletin I-O.04 - Legal aspects on searching persons on parole and
probation.
The Evaluation Coordinator for this order shall be the Training Section Commander, who,
without further notice, shall forward the required report to the Chief of Police on or by 02
Apr 16.
The Evaluation Coordinator shall forward a copy of the six-month evaluation report , along
with the comments/recommendations received, to the Bureau of Risk Management to be 
maintained in the appropriate Departmental Training Bulletin archive folder. 
Personnel shall acknowledge receipt, review, and understanding of this directive in
accordance with the provisions of DGO A-1, DEPARTMENTAL PUBLICATIONS. 
By order of
Howard A. Jordan 
Chiefof Police  Date Signed:

(cid:179)(cid:39)(cid:72)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:55)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:37)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)
 
procedures and shall con(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:73)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:92)(cid:17)(cid:180) 
 
 
THE LEGAL ASPECTS OF SEARCHING PERSONS 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION  
 
The purpose of this Training Bulletin is to identify the circumstances under which 
an officer may search detainees, arrested persons, and their possessions. 
 
The Fourth Amendment protects people against unreasonable searches and 
seizures. It is essential that officers understand the limitations the law imposes upon 
their conduct of a search. Police officers must constantly be aware of and comply 
with case law that describes conditions allowing searches and seizures by the 
government.  
 
State and Federal courts do not support and routinely suppress evidence that result 
from searches that unreasonably infringe on the reasonable expectation of privacy 
of the person searched. Additional consequences include violations of 
Departmental policy and claims of civil rights violations. 
 
The intrusiveness of a search is just one element of a search but easily the single 
most important in the reasonableness analysis conducted by State and Federal 
courts. For examp(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:179)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:3)
(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:180)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:74)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)
that must be justified with articulable facts that support the reasonableness of the 
search.  
 
Searches of people can be justified by a warrant, consent, exigency, or established 
case law decisions allowing such searches (e.g., incident to an arrest). Always 
assess the totality of circumstances surrounding a warrantless search and consider 
whether or not the search is reasonable under the circumstances. Case law 
regarding search and seizure can change each time a court decision is made. 
Officers are not expected to be able to cite court decisions but they are expected to 
understand what constitutes a reasonable search and seizure. When in doubt, call a 
supervisor to the scene.  
 
1 
 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document141   Filed04/18/13   Page10 of 21
 
 
Legal Aspects of Searching Persons, Index Number I-O.02
 
Questions regarding search and seizure can also be made to the Training Section 
for a referral to the appropriate subject matter expert. 
 
II.  SEARCH DEFINITIONS  
 
A.  (cid:179)(cid:41)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:92)(cid:180)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)ident to an arrest where the arrestee is going to be 
transported to the jail or the hospital) means a pat-down and thorough 
(cid:72)(cid:91)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:182)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)
possession. When multiple garments (jackets, pants, etc.) are worn, the 
outer garment may be removed for examination and to allow for 
examination of garments below the outer layer.  
 
Example: Front pants pockets are pulled out (reversed) and examined. Back 
pockets are entered by reaching inside and contents are removed. Hats, 
gloves, and shoes are removed and examined. Waistbands are examined. If 
suspected evidence, weapons, or contraband is discovered during a routine 
full body search, a more intrusive search (strip search) is allowed for the 
purpose of removing the item.  
 
B.  (cid:179)(cid:54)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:180)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3)
some or all of his or her clothing so as to permit a visual inspection of the 
underwear, brassiere, breasts, buttocks, or genitalia of such a person.  
 
C.  (cid:179)(cid:37)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:92)(cid:180)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)rectal cavity of a person, and vagina of a female 
person. The ear canals, nostrils, and throat are not body cavities.

IV.  CURSORY SEARCHES 
 
During a detention, you have no power to conduct a general, full, exploratory 
search of the suspect. However, you may conduct a patdown or limited weapons 
search of someone you have detained, but only: 
 
  For weapons,  
  Of the person(cid:182)s outer clothing, and  
  If you have specific facts which make you feel in danger.  
 
(cid:179)(cid:54)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:180)(cid:3)is not good enough. You must reasonably suspect that the 
person is armed or may be armed, although you do not need to be positive. The 
courts are quite supportive of your safety. But at the very least you need a 
potentially dangerous situation to justify a patdown search. Dealing with a 
suspected dangerous felon is by definition enough cause. However, pat searching 
the passenger of a vehicle stopped for a traffic infraction, with nothing more, is not 
justified.

V.  SEARCHES INCIDENT TO AN ARREST 
 
A.  Legal Requirements  
 
There are three requirements for a lawful search incident to an arrest:  
 
1.  The arrest must be legal. 
 
2.  The search must be contemporaneous with the arrest. As a general 
(cid:85)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:179)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:180)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)
same general time and the same general location as the arrest.  
However, the courts have allowed exceptions when the time lapse 
between arrest and search were attributable to reasonable police 
necessities. During a narcotics arrest, for example, when a hostile 
crowd gathered, police were allowed to interrupt the search of the 
suspect to move to a safer location in order to protect themselves 
and the arrested person. 
 
3.  The arrest must be custodial.  For the purpose of this Training 
(cid:37)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:179)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:180)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:17)(cid:3)
It is the custodial nature of the arrest and not the charge for which a 
person is arrested which justifies the search.  Searches incident to an 
arrest are not permissible when the arrest is not custodial and will be 
disposed of by a mere citation. 
 
B.  Scope and Type of Search Allowed 
 
1.  Scope of Search Allowed 
 
Generally, the scope of a search incident to an arrest is governed by 
the following rule:  An officer may conduct a full body search of the

2.  Type of Search Allowed 
 
Incident to an arrest, officers may conduct a full body search of a 
person for:

e.  Weapons which can be used to assault arresting officers or to

Officers may conduct full body searches of arrestees who are going 
to be transported to jail. Other searches which are incident to an 
arrest (i.e., containers, vehicles, surrounding areas) are also 
permissible and are discussed in Training Bulletin I-O.1 THE 
LEGAL ASPECTS OF SEARCHING VEHICLES.

VI.  SEARCHES OF PAROLEES AND PROBATIONERS 
 
Officers shall be respectful when engaging and providing service to the 
community. To help eliminate negative perceptions of peace officers(cid:182) conduct, 
officers are encouraged to focus on developing a rapport with community members 
and refrain from immediately asking if a person is on probation or parole. Such a 
question, especially if it is the first question asked, infers that the community 
member must have some sort of criminal history. Community members may view 
this line of questioning as disrespectful and as an assumption without merit.

VII.  STRIP SEARCHES IN THE FIELD 
 
A.  PURPOSE 
Field strip searches are significantly restricted by law.  Officers may be 
subject to liability under state and federal law for constitutional violations.  
Under Penal Code Section 4030, officers who use, participate in, or allow 
7 
 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document141   Filed04/18/13   Page16 of 21
 
 
Legal Aspects of Searching Persons, Index Number I-O.02
   
other officers to conduct field strip searches without justification or in a 
capricious or arbitrary manner may face criminal liability. 
 
The purpose of this policy is to:  
 
1.  Ensure compliance with legal standards applicable to field strip 
searches;  
 
2.  Establish policy requirements; and  
 
3.  Provide officers with guidelines for determining when and under 
what limited conditions the use of field strip searches are authorized 
by law and this policy.  
 
B.  POLICY  
The Department recognizes the intrusiveness of strip searches on individual 
privacy and the significant legal restrictions imposed by State and Federal 
law.  The use of strip searches may, under certain limited conditions, be 
necessary to protect the safety of officers and the public, and to detect and 
secure evidence of criminal activity.  Consistent with the law, the 
Department discourages the use of strip searches in the field.  It is the policy 
of the Department that strip searches in the field shall be conducted only 
under exigent circumstances and with the proper authority and justification.  
Field strip searches shall be conducted in accordance with the procedural 
guidelines as set forth in this policy and with due recognition and deference 
for the human dignity and privacy rights of those being searched. 
 
C.  DEFINITIONS 
1.  Strip Search 
 
A strip search is a search which requires a person to remove or 
arrange some or all of his or her clothing so as to permit a visual 
inspection of the underclothing, breasts, buttocks, or genitalia of 
such person (Penal Code 4030(c).) 
 
2.  Exigent Circumstances 
 
Exigent circumstances are circumstances where the immediate need 
to perform a field strip search outweighs the need to transport the 
prisoner to a jail facility and perform a strip search in the facility in 
accordance to PC 4030.  
8

02 Apr 13 (cid:135)(cid:3)(cid:50)(cid:68)(cid:78)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:51)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:39)(cid:72)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)
 
The following are examples of exigent circumstances that may 
prompt a field strip search: 
 
a.  The arrestee is making overt attempts to remove the 
concealed narcotics and orally ingest them. Ingestion of the 
narcotics can lead to choking or other medical emergency. 
 
b.  The arrestee is making overt movements to remove the 
concealed narcotics and destroy them. 
 
c.  The arrestee is suspected of concealing a weapon.  
 
3.  Field Strip Search 
 
A field strip search is a strip search as discussed above which is 
conducted outside of a jail facility and not as part of the booking 
process. 
 
D.  REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES 
1.  Field strip searches shall be conducted only on persons who are 
arrested, when an officer has independent probable cause to 
believe that the arrestee is concealing weapons or contraband, and 
under exigent circumstances where the life of officers or civilians 
may be at risk or evidence may be destroyed. The following 
requirements must be met: 
 
a.  Arrestee 
 
The person on whom the strip search is conducted must be 
an arrestee.  This also applies to probationers and parolees. 
 
b.  Probable Cause for Believing the Arrestee Is Concealing 
Evidence 
 
There must be probable cause to believe that the arrestee is 
concealing weapons, narcotics, or contraband and the strip 
search will lead to the discovery of items.   
 
c.  Urgency 
 
There must be an urgency requiring the recovery of the items 
in the field to safeguard officers and the public from harm, 
and to protect evidence from being destroyed.

afforded sufficient privacy so that undergarments or private

personnel.

If a strip search in the field is justified, officers shall conduct 
only limited, reach-in type strip searches.  Body cavity 
searches are prohibited. 
 
g.  Less Intrusive Searches  
 
Officers shall attempt to conduct less invasive searches first 
before proceeding to conduct a field strip search, unless the 
exigent circumstances warrant use of a field strip search to 
protect the safety of officers or the public.  
 
h.  Obtain Supervisory Approval 
 
Officers are required to obtain supervisory approval prior to 
conducting a field strip search.  The only exception is if a 
weapon or other situation requires immediate action to 
protect the safety of officers or the public.  The approval 
may be verbal.  If prior approval is not possible due to 
exigency, officers shall inform a supervisor as soon as 
possible after the search.  
 
i.   Communications Notification 
 
When a field strip search is conducted, officers shall notify 
the Communications Division by using disposition code 
FSSC (Field Strip Search Conducted). 
 
j.  Documentation 
 
The use of field strip searches shall be documented in the 
appropriate report and the report shall be approved by the 
field supervisor.  The following information shall be 
documented: 
 
1)  Probable cause for the underlying arrest. 
2)  Probable cause for believing that the arrestee is 
concealing a weapon, drugs or other contraband.  
3)  Exigency that required the immediate recovery of the 
items. 
4)  Identity of the supervisor contacted and whether prior 
approval was obtained or not.

heroin v(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:182)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:17) 
 
 
 
12 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document141   Filed04/18/13   Page21 of 21
 
02 Apr 13 (cid:135)(cid:3)(cid:50)(cid:68)(cid:78)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:51)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:39)(cid:72)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)
 
B.  Obtaining Blood Samples  
 
Reasonable force can be used to obtain a blood sample from an arrestee 
when obtaining a blood sample is necessary to preserve evidence. Using 
reasonable force to obtain a blood sample may be justified, for example, in 
DUI incidents that result in property damage, injury, and/or a fatality. With 
(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:91)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:83)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:39)(cid:56)(cid:44)(cid:182)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3)all other circumstances where consent is not given, 
a warrant is required to obtain a blood sample.  
 
As a general rule, a sample of blood may be obtained whether or not the 
defendant is conscious.

4 A. Plaintiff Darnell Foster

1 C. Plaintiff Yancie Young
2 Plaintiff Young is an African-American man.  At approximately 11:30 p.m. on September
3 30, 2003 Young was pulled over by Officer Bergeron around the 2800 block of West Street in
4 Oakland.  Officer Bergeron opened Youngโs car door, pulled him out of the car and handcuffed him. 
5 Officer Bergeron asked Young if he was on probation or parole, which Young denied.  Officer
6 Bergeron insisted that he smelled marijuana in Youngโs car and suggested that Young was
7 smuggling large quantities of the drug.  
8 Officer Bergeron then took Young to the back of a police car.  While facing Young, he
9 pulled down Youngโs pants and underwear, revealing Youngโs genitalia.  Then Officer Bergeron
10 shined a flashlight directed at Youngโs genitalia, visually inspecting Young for up to a minute. 
11 Officer Bergeron next performed a pat-search of Young, ordered Young to remove his shoes and felt
12 Youngโs private area through his pants.  Another officer searched Youngโs car during the search of
T a
UR rni 13 Youngโs person.  No contraband was found.

21 D. Defendants
22 Defendant Oakland is a municipal corporation, which operates the Oakland Police
23 Department (โOPDโ) and employs the additional defendants named below.  Defendant Richard
24 Word is Chief of Police for Oakland.  Plaintiffs have sued him in both his individual and official

27 Gregory Loud, Sean Bowling, Wayne Tucker, R. Alcantar, O. Crum, J. Foreman, L. Leonis,  S.

Case 3:06-cv-02426-MHP     Document 28      Filed 03/27/2008     Page 6 of 24
1 Valle and Does 1-25 were police officers for Oakland at all times mentioned herein.  They have been
2 sued in both their individual and official capacities.3 
3   1. Oakland Police Departmentโs Policy Before 2004
4 The Oakland Police Departmentโs 1998 policy, entitled โStrip Searches, Visual Body-Cavity
5 Searches, and Physical Body-Cavity Searchesโ appears in the OPDโs 1998 Training Bulletin.4 
6 Defs.โ Opp., Exh. A (โ1998 Policyโ).   The policy begins by defining the terms โstrip search,โ
7 โvisual body-cavity searchโ and โphysical body-cavity search.โ  Id. at 8.  A strip search is โany
8 search that requires the officer to remove or arrange some or all of a personโs clothing to permit a
9 visual inspection of the subjectโs underclothing, breasts, buttocks, or genitals.โ  Id.  A visual body
10 cavity search is โa search which consists of the visual inspection of the subjectโs rectal cavity and, if
11 the subject is a female, vagina.  A visual body-cavity search does not include a search of the mouth.โ 
12 Id.  A physical body cavity search is โa search which consists of the physical intrusion into a body
T a
UR rni 13 cavity for the purpose of discovering a concealed object.โ  Id.  The policy next stipulates that four
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 requirements must be met before a strip search or a visual body cavity search may be performed: (1)
C f 
I o
R t  15 โ[t]he person to be searched must be under arrest and ultimately booked;โ (2) โ[t]he arrest must be
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 for an offense involving weapons, controlled substances, or violence;โ (3) โ[t]he person conducting
ES  n 
T er 17 the search must be of the same sex as the person searched;โ and (4) โ[t]he search must be conducted
A h
T rt
So
D  N 18 in a private area where it cannot be observed by persons not participating in the search.โ  Id. 
E e 
h
NIT or t 19 Additionally, the policy specifies that a physical body cavity search requires a warrant.  Id.
UF
20 The Bulletin also discusses the permissible scope of pat searches and the requirements for
21 searches incident to arrest.  Id. at 2โ8.  To perform a search incident to arrest, three requirements
22 must be met: (1) โ[t]he arrest must be legal;โ (2) โ[t]he search must be contemporaneous with the
23 arrest;โ and (3) โ[t]he arrest must be custodial.โ  Id. at 7.  The policy on searches incident to arrest
24 also states that an officer may search a person for contraband with probable cause.  Id.  
25 2. Oakland Police Departmentโs Amended Policy
26 In 2004 the Oakland Police Department amended its policy on strip and body-cavity
27 searches.  The amendments came in response to public concerns regarding the Departmentโs practice
28
6

Case 3:06-cv-02426-MHP     Document 28      Filed 03/27/2008     Page 7 of 24
1 of carrying out such searches.  The Department publicly identified a โlong-standing and problematic
2 practice of conducting strip searches in the field.โ  Burris Dec., Exh. C at 4.  
3 Similar to the 1998 Policy, the 2004 Training Bulletin defines the three types of strip
4 searches, discusses the permissible scope of pat searches and outlines the requirements for searches
5 incident to arrest.  Id., Exh. G (โ2004 Policyโ) at 1โ6.  Specifically, the 1998 requirements for
6 performing a strip search were significantly amended in 2004.  Id. at 6.  In the 2004 Bulletin, the
7 section relevant to strip searches is entitled โStrip Searches in the Field.โ  Id.  The policy stipulates
8 that a โstrip search incident to an arrestโ may only be performed when: (1) โ[i]t is reasonable to
9 believe that the arrestee is concealing a weapon;โ or (2) โit is reasonable to believe that the arrestee
10 is concealing evidence or contraband;โ and (3) โthat evidence may be destroyed or ingested unless it
11 is immediately recovered.โ  Id. (emphases omitted).  The policy goes on to say that warrantless strip
12 searches โare not justified by the arrest itself,โ and that one must have โreasonable suspicion that the
T a
UR rni 13 arrestee has concealed a weapon, contraband or evidence.โ  Id. (emphasis omitted). 
O o
f
CT  Cali 14   Additionally, the 2004 Policy states that a strip search in the field may not be performed
C f 
I o
R t  15 unless the following requirements are met: (1) the officer has โreasonable suspicion to believe the
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 arrestee is hiding or concealing evidence, a weapon, or contraband;โ (2) the officer is โof the same
ES  n 
T er 17 sex as the arrestee unless there is an exigency and an officer of the same sex is not available to
A h
T rt
So
D  N 18 respond;โ (3) the officer โmay not have physical contact with the arrestee except contact that is
E e 
h
NIT or t 19 reasonably necessary to search for and recover items and to control or direct the arrestee;โ (4) โthe
UF
20 search must be conducted so that the search cannot be easily observed by the public,โ and
21 โreasonable efforts must be made to provide as much privacy as possible;โ and (5) the officer โmust
22 document the search and the need to conduct the search in the field in the appropriate report.โ  Id.
23 at 7 (emphases omitted).  Notably, the 2004 Policy explicitly prohibits officers from ever conducting
24 a physical or visual body cavity search in the field.  Id.  
25
26
27
28
7

Case 3:06-cv-02426-MHP     Document 28      Filed 03/27/2008     Page 8 of 24
1 3. Oakland Police Departmentโs Alleged Practice
2 Plaintiffs allege that there is a widespread practice of public strip and body cavity searches
3 within the Oakland Police Department that deviates from the Departmentโs recently revised policy. 
4 Plaintiffs claim that this practice occurs without regard to the privacy of subjects being searched. 
5 Subjectsโ genitalia, buttocks, and/or anuses are exposed, often without any screen from public view. 
6 This practice allegedly targets racial minoritiesโespecially Hispanic- and African-Americans.  
7
8 II. Procedural History
9 Plaintiffs Foster and Duarte filed the present action on August 1, 2005.  Pursuant to
10 stipulations, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on September 22, 2005 adding plaintiff Young. 
11 Additionally, the following actions were related to this action: (1) Rider v. City of Oakland, No. C
12 05-3204 MHP, related on October 6, 2005; (2) Taylor v. City of Oakland, No. C 04-4843 MHP,
T a
UR rni 13 related on October 6, 2005; (3) Moore v. City of Oakland, No. C 06-02426 MHP, related on July 12,
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 2006; and (4) Miller v. City of Oakland, No. C 07-1773 MHP, related on April 17, 2007.
C f 
I o
R t  15 Plaintiffsโ motion to certify a class was denied on January 27, 2007 for failure to satisfy the
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 requirement of numerosity.  Docket No. 42.  Plaintiffs now move for partial summary judgment on
ES  n 
T er 17 the following grounds: 1) declaratory relief that the 1998 Policy is unconstitutional; 2) declaratory
A h
T rt
So
D  N 18 relief that the 2004 amended Policy is unconstitutional; 3) judgment that any search in accordance
E e 
h
NIT or t 19 with either of the policies is unconstitutional; 4) summary judgment on the issue of liability in favor
UF
20 of plaintiffs.  Plaintiffs have not moved for summary judgment on claims related to the OPDโs
21 alleged practice.
22
23 LEGAL STANDARD
24 Summary judgment is proper when the pleadings, discovery and affidavits show that there is
25 โno genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a
26 matter of law.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c).  Material facts are those which may affect the outcome of the
27 case.  Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A dispute as to a material fact is
28
8

Case 3:06-cv-02426-MHP     Document 28      Filed 03/27/2008     Page 9 of 24
1 genuine if there is sufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to return a verdict for the nonmoving
2 party.  Id.  The party moving for summary judgment bears the burden of identifying those portions
3 of the pleadings, discovery and affidavits that demonstrate the absence of a genuine issue of material
4 fact.  Celotex Corp. v. Cattrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323 (1986).  On an issue for which the opposing party
5 will have the burden of proof at trial, the moving party need only point out โthat there is an absence
6 of evidence to support the nonmoving partyโs case.โ  Id.
7 Once the moving party meets its initial burden, the nonmoving party must go beyond the
8 pleadings and, by its own affidavits or discovery, โset forth specific facts showing that there is a
9 genuine issue for trial.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e).  Mere allegations or denials do not defeat a moving
10 partyโs allegations.  Id.; Gasaway v. Nw. Mut. Life Ins. Co., 26 F.3d 957, 960 (9th Cir.
11 1994).  The court may not make credibility determinations, and inferences to be drawn from the
12 facts must be viewed in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.  Masson v. New
T a
UR rni 13 Yorker Magazine, 501 U.S. 496, 520 (1991); Anderson, 477 U.S. at 249.
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 The moving party may โmove with or without supporting affidavits for a summary judgment
C f 
I o
R t  15 in the partyโs favor upon all [claims] or any part thereof.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a).  โSupporting and
T c
S ri
DI Dist 16 opposing affidavits shall be made on personal knowledge, shall set forth such facts as would be
ES  n 
T er 17 admissible in evidence, and shall show affirmatively that the affiant is competent to testify to the
A h
T rt
So
D  N 18 matters stated therein.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e).
E e 
h
NIT or t 19
UF
20 DISCUSSION
21 Plaintiffs seek partial summary judgment on four grounds: 1) declaratory relief that the 1998
22 Policy is unconstitutional; 2) declaratory relief that the 2004 amended Policy is unconstitutional;
23 3) judgment that any search in accordance with either of the policies is unconstitutional; 4) summary
24 judgment on the issue of liability in favor of plaintiffs.  The thrust of plaintiffsโ argument is that the
25 OPD policies should be found unconstitutional as a matter of law because the policies: 1) do not
26 allow for individualized suspicion; 2) permit invasive searches of an arresteeโs person upon less than
27
28
9

Case 3:06-cv-02426-MHP     Document 28      Filed 03/27/2008     Page 10 of 24
1 probable cause; 3) do not adequately protect a suspectโs constitutionally protected right to physical
2 privacy; and 4) permit warrantless searches in circumstances in which a warrant is required. 
3
4 I. Fourth Amendment Requirements
5 The instant action presents an issue of first impression to the extent that it implicates Fourth
6 Amendment restraints on strip searches performed outside the traditional setting of a police station
7 or detention facility.  Before addressing the constitutionality of the OPDโs 1998 and 2004 strip
8 search policies, it is useful to review the case law describing the requirements of the Fourth
9 Amendment in similar contexts.  The Supreme Court has noted that there is no precise formula for
10 reconciling the competing interests of law enforcement and individual privacy with respect to
11 searches and seizures: 
12 The test for reasonableness under the Fourth Amendment is not capable of
T a precise definition or mechanical application.  In each case it requires a
UR rni 13 balancing of the need for the particular search against the invasion of
O fo personal rights that the search entails.  Courts must consider the scope of
CT  Cali 14 the  particular  intrusion,  the  manner  in  which  it  is  conducted,  the
C f  justification for initiating it, and the place in which it is conducted. 
I o
R t  15
T c
S ri Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 559 (1979).  
DI Dist 16
ES  n   โState law is also relevant in analyzing the reasonableness of a search under the Fourth
T er 17
A h
T rt Amendment.โ  Edgerly v. City and County of San Francisco, 495 F.3d 645, 656 (9th Cir. 2007).
So
D  N 18
E e  The Ninth Circuit has had occasion to determine the constitutionality of various strip search
h
UNIT For t 19 policies employed by law-enforcement agencies.  See, e.g., Giles v. Ackerman, 746 F.2d 614 (9th
20
Cir. 1984); Kennedy v. Los Angeles Police Depโt, 901 F.2d 702 (9th Cir. 1990); Fuller v. M.G.
21
Jewelry, 950 F.2d 1437 (9th Cir. 1991).  There are two significant differences between the policies
22
examined in this line of cases and the policy at issue in the instant action.  First, the policies
23
considered in those cases were blanket strip search policies requiring that an arrestee be subjected to
24
a strip search if the arrestee met certain criteria, e.g., if the arrestee was arrested on suspicion of
25
committing a felony.  See, e.g., Kennedy, 901 F.2d at 713 (holding that the Los Angeles Police
26
Departmentโs blanket cavity search policy for felony arrests was unconstitutional).  The OPD
27
28
10

Case 3:06-cv-02426-MHP     Document 28      Filed 03/27/2008     Page 11 of 24
1 policies do not require that a strip search be performed at any time; they only define when a strip
2 search is permissible.  1998 Policy at 8; 2004 Policy at 6โ7.  Where the Ninth Circuit has found
3 blanket strip search policies to be unconstitutional, they have done so pursuant to the Supreme
4 Courtโs balancing test articulated in Bell.  To be clear, the OPD policies are not blanket strip search
5 policies, and therefore do not risk violating the Supreme Courtโs balancing test on that ground. 
6 Second, the previous cases have all considered strip search policies that contemplate searches
7 occurring post-arrest and pre-booking at a police station or other detention facility.  See Giles, 746
8 F.2d at 617 (strip search of woman at county jail pursuant to a blanket jail policy held
9 unconstitutional); Kennedy, 901 F.2d at 713 (strip search of woman at jail pursuant to a blanket jail
10 policy held unconstitutional); Fuller, 950 F. 2d at 1449โ50 (strip search of woman at Los Angeles
11 Police Department central station pursuant to a blanket policy held unconstitutional).  None have
12 considered strip searches occurring in the field.5 
T a
UR rni 13 The term โstrip searchโ has been variously defined by applicable law.  It is specifically
O o
f
CT  Cali 14 defined by the California Penal Code, section 4030(c) as โa search which requires a person to
C f 
I o
R t  15 remove or arrange some or all of his or her clothing so as to permit a visual inspection of the

1 IV. Constitutionality of Individual Searches
2 Plaintiffs seek summary judgment declaring any search in accordance with either of the OPD
3 policies to be unconstitutional.  The constitutionality of an individual search, however, does not turn
4 solely on the constitutionality of the policy pursuant to which it was performed.  See Kennedy, 901
5 F.2d at 715.  The Ninth Circuit observed in Kennedy that โa search, although not supportable under
6 an institutional policy, is not per se unconstitutional.โ  Id.  And in Fuller, the court noted that โ[t]he
7 fundamental question under the fourth amendment is whether โthe grounds for a search . . . satisfy
8 objective standardsโ of reasonableness.โ  950 F.2d at 1446 (quoting Torres v. Commonwealth of
9 Puerto Rico, 442 U.S. 465, 471 (1979)) (emphasis omitted).  Thus, even if a policy permitting a
10 search passes constitutional muster, an individual search must be evaluated based upon the above
11 standards.  Where a policy permits searches that may be unconstitutional, an individual search must
12 still meet constitutional standards.  Where the officer claims to rely on an unconstitutional policy,

11 police station or detention center, contrary to plaintiffsโ repeated implication that โin the fieldโ is
synonymous with โin public.โ  Former OPD Chief Richard Wordโs internal communication indicates
12
that an appropriate place for a field search would be inside an unoccupied private or public
T a
UR rni 13 restroom; it would be a stretch to characterize a search conducted in such surroundings as a search
O o
f โin public.โ  Nisenbaum Dec., Exh. A at 33.
CT  Cali 14
IC of  6. Since, as can be seen from this sentence, the term โstrip searchโ has been used to denote a
R t  15
ST ric wide variety of search practices varying in their degree of intrusiveness, this court, as stated above,
DI Dist 16 uses the California Penal Code definitions.
ES  n 
T er 17 7. In some rare instances, the probable cause for the arrest will also provide probable cause for
A h
ST ort the invasive search.
D  N 18
E e 
h
UNIT For t 19 8P.olicy dDisecsupsistee dth bee cloownt riand siecctotiroyn l aIInIg oufa gthei sw oitrhd erre,s tpheec t2 0to0 4th Pe orleiqcuyi msitoer ele cvleela orlfy s suusgpgiceisotns  tihna tth teh e2004
20 separate sections of the Training Bulletin must be read together by defining the requirements for
โstrip searches incident to arrest.โ  2004 Policy at 6 (emphasis added).  This suggests that strip
21
searches may only be performed when the requirements for searches incident to arrest are met. 
22 While the 1998 Policy does not make this clear on its face, plaintiffs have presented no evidence to
the contrary, and the court accepts defendantsโ argument that the sections must be read together. 
23
9. While the Fourth Amendment requirement for conducting a strip search is reasonableness
24
under the circumstances, California Penal Code section 4030(m) appears to require strict privacy:
25 โ[a]ll strip, visual and physical body cavity searches shall be conducted in an area of privacy so that
the search cannot be observed by persons not participating in the search.โ
26
10. The 2004 OPD Policy notes in the same sentence that a physical body cavity search can only
27
be conducted by an authorized medical professional.  2004 Policy at 7.
28
23

documents.text:
Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page1 of 13
1 JOHN L. BURRIS, Esq./ State Bar #69888
BENJAMIN NISENBAUM, Esq./State Bar #222173
2 LAW OFFICES OF JOHN L. BURRIS
Airport Corporate Centre
3 7677 Oakport Street, Suite 1120
Oakland, California 94621
4 Telephone:  (510) 839-5200
Facsimile:   (510) 839-3882
5
Attorneys for Plaintiffs
6
7 UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
8 FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
9
10 DARNELL FOSTER, individually; RAFAEL  Case No.
DUARTE, individually,
11 COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES FOR
VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS.
Plaintiffs,
12 JURY TRIAL DEMANDED
vs.
13
CITY OF OAKLAND,  a municipal corporation;
14
RICHARD WORD, in his capacity as Chief of
15 Police for the CITY OF OAKLAND; J.
FESTAG, individually and in his capacity as a
16
police officer for the CITY OF OAKLAND;
and,  DOES 1-25, inclusive,
17
18                                              Defendants.
                                                                            /
19
20
21
JURISDICTION
22
1. This action arises under Title 42 of the United States Code, Section 1983.  Jurisdiction
23
is conferred upon this Court by Title 28 of the United States Code, Sections 1331 and 1343.  The
24
unlawful acts and practices alleged herein occurred in the County of Alameda, California, which is
25
within this judicial district.
26
27
28
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 1

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page2 of 13
1 PARTIES
2 2. Plaintiff herein, DARNELL FOSTER (โFOSTERโ), is readily recognizable as an
3 African-American male and was at all times herein mentioned a citizen of the United States residing
4 in Alameda County in California.
5 3. Plaintiff herein, RAFAEL DUARTE (โDUARTEโ), is readily recognizable as an
6 Hispanic-American was at all times herein mentioned a citizen of the United States residing in
7 Alameda County in California.
8 4. Defendant City of Oakland (โCITYโ) is a municipal corporation, duly organized and
9 existing under the laws of the State of California.  The City operates under its authority the Oakland
10 Police Department.
11 5. At all times mentioned herein, Defendant RICHARD WORD was employed by
12 Defendant CITY as Chief of Police for the Defendant CITY.  He is being sued in his official capacity
13 as Chief of Police for the City.
14 6. At all times mentioned herein, Defendant officer J. FESTAG (โFESTAGโ) was
15 employed by Defendant CITY as a police officer.  He is being sued individually and in his official
16 capacity as a police officer for the City.
17 7. Plaintiffs are ignorant of the true names and capacities of Defendants DOES 1 through
18 25, inclusive, and therefore sue these defendants by such fictitious names.  Plaintiffs are informed
19 and believe and thereon allege that each Defendant so named is responsible in some manner for the
20 injuries and damages sustained by Plaintiffs as set forth herein.  Plaintiffs will amend their complaint
21 to state the names and capacities of DOES 1-25, inclusive, when they have been ascertained.
22 8. In engaging in the conduct described herein, Defendant police officers acted under the
23 color of law and in the course and scope of their employment with the City.  In engaging in the
24 conduct described herein, Defendant police officers exceeded the authority vested in them as police
25 officers under the United States and California Constitutions and as police officers employed by
26 Defendant CITY.
27
28
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 2

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page3 of 13
1 STATEMENT OF FACTS
2 FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS REGARDING PLAINTIFF DARNELL FOSTER
3 9. On February 27, 2004, at around 3 p.m., Defendant Officer FESTAG stopped Plaintiff
4 FOSTER in front of a small market, the โSchool Marketโ, located near the corner of School Street
5 and Pleitner Avenue in Oakland, Caifornia.
6 10. Plaintiff FOSTER lived in Carson City, Nevada at the time, but was visiting friends
7 who lived in Oakland.  Plaintiff FOSTER had purchased two Black and Mild cigars at the School
8 Market shortly before Defendant Officer FESTAG and one other unknown Oakland Police Officer
9 DOE stopped him.  He possessed no contraband and was not engaged in any illegal activity
10 whatsoever.  Defendant Officers stopped Plaintiff FOSTER as he walked out of the School Market
11 and asked him for his identification.   Plaintiff FOSTER showed the officer his identification.  The
12 officers then asked him whether he was on probation or parole.  Plaintiff FOSTER honestly replied
13 that he was on probation. In fact, Plaintiff FOSTER,  only two months remained of the five year
14 felony unsupervised probation sentence for possession for sale of marijuana. Plaintiff FOSTER had
15 served his probation sentence without incurring  a single violation.  Plaintiff FOSTER told Defendant
16 Officer FESTAG that he had only two months remaining on his probation.
17 11. Defendant Officer FESTAG handcuffed Plaintiff FOSTER without explanation and
18 escorted him to the back of his patrol vehicle, which was parked in front of the School Market.
19 Defendant Officer FESTAG forced Plaintiff FOSTER against the back of the patrol vehicle and
20 ordered him to spread his legs.  Defendant Officer FESTAG searched Plaintiff FOSTERโs pockets
21 and found $22.  Defendant Officer FESTAG told Plaintiff FOSTER that the $22 would be
22 confiscated.  Even though Plaintiff FOSTER had committed no crime and was not involved in any
23 manner of illegal activity, Defendant Officer FESTAG informed Plaintiff FOSTER that the $22
24 found in Plaintiff FOSTERโs pocket was proceeds of narcotics sales.  Defendant Officer FESTAG
25 claimed that Plaintiff FOSTER was engaged in narcotics sales.  He handcuffed Plaintiff FOSTER and
26 placed him in the rear of the police vehicle.
27 12. The unknown Officer DOE ran Plaintiff FOSTERโs name for a warrant check.  The
28 search revealed no warrants for Plaintiff FOSTER.  Defendant Officer FESTAG searched the area
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 3

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page4 of 13
1 around the market and located no evidence of any illegal activity relating to Plaintiff FOSTER.  In
2 spite of the circumstances, which overwhelmingly indicated that Plaintiff FOSTER had not
3 committed any crime, Defendant Officer FESTAG maliciously told Plaintiff FOSTER that he was
4 going to violate his probation.  Defendant Officer FESTAG told Plaintiff FOSTER, โI think youโre
5 holding out on me,โ even though there was no basis to believe that Plaintiff FOSTER was engaged in
6 illegal activity.
7 13. Defendant Officer FESTAG removed Plaintiff FOSTER, still handcuffed, from the
8 back of the patrol vehicle and bent him over the hood of the police car. Defendant Officer FESTAG
9 opened the patrol vehicleโs trunk and put on a purple latex glove.   He then returned to Plaintiff
10 FOSTER and ordered him to bend over the hood of the patrol vehicle. Plaintiff FOSTER stood in the
11 gutter, between the sidewalk and the police car, handcuffed, while Defendant Officer FESTAG
12 yanked Plaintiff FOSTERโs gray sweat pants down to his knees.  Defendant Officer FESTAG then
13 yanked Plaintiff FOSTERโs boxer shorts down to his knees, exposing Plaintiff FOSTERโs genitalia.
14 Humiliated and stunned, Plaintiff FOSTER felt Defendant Officer FESTAGโs hands reach under his
15 testicles.  Consistent with Plaintiff FOSTERโs  innocence, this offensive sexual battery showed that
16 Plaintiff FOSTER possessed no contraband at all.
17 14.  To Plaintiffโs shock and disbelief, Defendant Officer FESTAG told Plaintiff FOSTER
18 โIโm going to do a butt-crack search, see if you got crack in your butt-crack.โ  Plaintiff FOSTER was
19 forced to comply with Defendant Officer FESTAGโs outrageous conduct.  Defendant Officer
20 FESTAG spread Plaintiff FOSTERโs butt-cheeks with his right hand and exposed the anus.  The
21 unknown Officer DOE was also present, and both officers inspected Plaintiff FOSTERโs anus.
22 Predictably, this unwarranted intrusive search failed to reveal any contraband.
23 15. Defendant Officers pulled Plaintiffโs underwear and sweat pants up and put him back
24 in the rear of the patrol vehicle.  Despite the complete lack of evidence, Defendant Officer FESTAG
25 told Plaintiff that he was going to take him to jail for โloitering with the intent to sell narcotics.โ
26 Plaintiff FOSTER denied loitering and told the officers that he had just gone to the store, and was not
27 involved in any drug activity.
28
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 4

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page5 of 13
1 16. Defendant Officer FESTAG drove about two blocks away and stopped the patrol
2 vehicle near the corner of Texas and Maple Streets.  One of the Defendant Officers asked Plaintiff
3 FOSTER if he knew anyone who sold marijuana. When Plaintiff FOSTER said โno,โ the officers
4 asked him to make an undercover drug purchase.   After Plaintiff FOSTER refused to become a
5 snitch for the officers, Defendant Officer FESTAG told Plaintiff FOSTER โHelp me so I can help
6 you.โ
7 17. Plaintiff FOSTER again asked the officers what he had done, and they again claimed
8 that he had sold narcotics. When Plaintiff FOSTER truthfully stated that he had not sold narcotics,
9 the officers insisted that Plaintiff FOSTER sign a citation for violating an Oakland Municipal
10 Ordinance prohibiting loitering with the intent to sell narcotics.  Plaintiff FOSTER signed the citation
11 and Defendant Officer released him.  Defendant Officers kept Plaintiff FOSTER handcuffed
12 throughout the incident, which lasted nearly half an hour.
13 18. After being released, Plaintiff FOSTER returned to the same store, โSchool Marketโ
14 and spoke with the store clerk.  The clerk told Plaintiff FOSTER that one of the officers had come in
15 and asked him how long Plaintiff FOSTER had been in the store.  The clerk stated that he had told
16 the officer Mr. FOSTER had come into the store just before the police came.
17 19. Plaintiff FOSTER returned home to Carson City, Nevada.  Several months later, in
18 May, Plaintiff FOSTER received a Notice to Appear in Criminal court in Oakland in September 2004
19 on the citation issued by Defendant Officer FESTAG.    Plaintiff FOSTER called the Oakland Police
20 Department Internal Affairs Division and filed an Internal Affairs complaint against Defendant
21 Officer FESTAG sometime around July 2004.   In order to defend against the false loitering charges,
22 Plaintiff FOSTER traveled from Nevada to Oakland and appeared in court in Oakland on September
23 24, 2004.  The charge against him was dismissed when neither Officer FESTAG, nor any other
24 officer, appeared in court to substantiate the false allegation against Plaintiff FOSTER.
25 20. Plaintiff FOSTER alleges, on information and belief, that defendant officers had
26 insufficient information, and no particularized facts, to support their stop, detention, and search of
27 Plaintiff.
28
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 5

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page6 of 13
1 21. The detention, search, and arrest of Plaintiff FOSTER described herein was done
2 without any just provocation or cause, proximately causing Plaintiff FOSTERโs injuries and resulting
3 damages.
4 22. Plaintiff FOSTER alleges on information and belief that defendant officers performed
5 the public, intrusive anal-cavity search without probable or reasonable cause pursuant to an official or
6 de facto CITY OF OAKLAND policy condoning and/or ratifying such illegal searches
7 FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS REGARDING PLAINTIFF RAFAEL DUARTE
8 23. On the afternoon of March 9, 2005, Plaintiff RAFAEL DUARTE was a passenger in a
9 car driven by a friend of his, Deandre Wash. Mr. Wash drove a late-80s model Toyota Supra. Two
10 all-black Oakland Police vehicles, believed to be โtask-forceโ vehicles, cut the Supra off without
11 warning, forcing the car  to a sudden stop on Baker Street between, between 62nd and 63rd Street in
12 Oakland.
13 24. Although the Officers gave no orders to Plaintiff or Mr. Wash, at least one Defendant
14 Officer DOE opened the passenger side door and yanked Plaintiff DUARTE from the vehicle.
15 Although Plaintiff DUARTE had committed no crime, the DOE police officer forced him against the
16 Toyotaโs hood and handcuffed him.  The DOE police officer then walked Plaintiff DUARTE to the
17 front-side of a nearby house.   Several other unknown Defendant Officer DOES were also present at
18 the scene.  The DOE police officer pat-searched Plaintiff DUARTE several times and then searched
19 him thoroughly.  The search yielded no contraband.
20 26. Plaintiff DUARTE protested, stating that he had not committed any crime and was not
21 in possession of any contraband.  Even though the searches performed by  Officer DOE confirmed
22 that Plaintiff DUARTE had committed no crime and possessed no contraband, one other Defendant
23 Officer DOE 2 told the first Officer DOE that he thought he had seen Plaintiff DUARTE โstuff
24 something in his pants.โ
25 27. Defendant Officers pulled Plaintiff DUARTEโs pants down and ordered him to bend
26 over.  To Plaintiff DUARTEโs shock and humiliation, one of the Defendant Officer DOES spread
27 Plaintiff DUARTEโs butt-cheeks exposing his anus.  The search proved fruitless.  Plaintiff DUARTE
28 possessed no contraband anywhere.
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 6

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page7 of 13
1 28. Plaintiff DUARTE was placed in the rear of the police vehicle.  Defendant Officers
2 then removed Plaintiffโs friend, Mr. Wash, from the vehicle and performed the same type of anal-
3 cavity search on Mr. WASH.  That search also yielded no contraband whatsoever.  A crowd of
4 people had gathered during the search, and Plaintiff DUARTE was acquainted with some of the
5 people who witnessed the outrageous anal-cavity search of Plaintiff and his friend, Mr. Wash.
6 29. Plaintiff DUARTE was transported to Oakland City Jail where he was cited out after
7 about two hours in custody. Plaintiff DUARTE told the officer who took his fingerprints about the
8 anal-cavity search and was told by the officer to file an Internal Affairs complaint.  He was also told
9 that his civil rights had been violated and that he should file a lawsuit.  No charges were ever filed
10 against Plaintiff DUARTE.
11 30.  Plaintiff DUARTE alleges, on information and belief, that defendant officers had
12 insufficient information, and no particularized facts, to support their stop, detention, and search of
13 Plaintiff.
14 31. The detention, search, and arrest of Plaintiff DUARTE described herein was done
15 without any just provocation or cause, proximately causing Plaintiff DUARTEโs injuries and
16 resulting damages.
17 32. Plaintiff DUARTE alleges on information and belief that defendant officers performed
18 the public, intrusive anal-cavity search without probable or reasonable cause pursuant to an official or
19 de facto CITY OF OAKLAND policy condoning and/or ratifying such illegal searches
20
21 DAMAGES
22 33. As a proximate result of Defendantsโ conduct, Plaintiffs suffered severe and extreme
23 emotional distress, fear, terror, anxiety, humiliation, and loss of their sense of security, dignity, and
24 pride as United States citizens.
25 34. Plaintiffs were assaulted, detained, handcuffed, illegally searched in the anus in public,
26 and falsely arrested by the  defendant officers noted herein without any just provocation or probable
27 cause.  Plaintiff FOSTER defended against the false charge of loitering and traveled from Nevada to
28 Oakland to make a court appearance at which Defendant Officer FESTAG did not bother to appear.
COMPLAINT FOR VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND DAMAGES - 7

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document1    Filed08/01/05   Page8 of 13
1 35. The conduct of defendant officers was malicious, wanton, and oppressive.  Plaintiffs
2 are therefore entitled to an award of punitive damages against said defendant police officers.
3 36. Plaintiffs found it necessary to engage the services of private counsel to vindicate his
4 rights under the law.  Plaintiffs are therefore entitled to an award of all attorneyโs fees incurred in
5 relation to this action for violation of their civil rights.
6
7 FIRST CAUSE OF ACTION
(42 U.S.C. Section 1983)
8
(Against Defendants FESTAG and DOES 1-10)
9
37. Plaintiffs hereby re-allege and incorporate by reference herein paragraphs 1 through
10
36 of this Complaint.
11
38. In doing the acts complained of herein, Defendants FESTAG and DOES 1-10,
12
13 inclusive, and/or each of them, acted under color of law to deprive Plaintiffs of certain
14
constitutionally protected rights, including, but not limited to:
15
a.  The right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures, as guaranteed by the
16
Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution;
17
18 b.  The right not to be deprived of life or liberty without due process of law, as guaranteed
19
by the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution;
20
c.  The right to be free from the use of excessive force by police officers, which is
21
guaranteed  by the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States
22
Constitution;
23
24 d.  The right to equal protection of the laws, as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment
25
to the United States Constitution;  and/or,
26
e.  The right to be free from interference within the zone of privacy, as protected by the
27
Fourth and Ninth Amendments to the United States Constitution;
28
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs pray for relief as hereinafter set forth.

25
ranking  City  of  Oakland  officials,  including  high  ranking  City  of  Oakland  Police  Department
26
supervisors, Defendants WORD, DOES 11-25, and each of them resulted in the deprivation of
27
Plaintffsโ constitutional rights including, but not limited to, the following:
