24 The court has reviewed the filings in the foregoing cases referring particularly to C-08-4255
25 and C-09-5316.  It appears that the latter action was related to the constellation of cases related to 
26 C-04-4843 by order dated February 17, 2010, but that the earlier of the two cases was not related
27 although it had been assigned to this judge.  Apparently no proposed order was submitted and no
28 //
2

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document112   Filed03/04/10   Page3 of 4
1 action was actually taken relating that case.  Therefore, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that C-08-
2 4255MHP is deemed related to C-04-4843MHP.
3 The court also notes in reviewing these two cases that a disturbing pattern seems to be
4 emerging.  Claims are being misjoined, for in both of these cases there are individuals making
5 claims that although they may be related as to common questions of law, do not allege incidents
6 occurring on the same date or involving the same facts, persons or officers.  Each of the incidents
7 complained of  in these cases is separate and distinct.  
8 Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 18(a) provides that โ[a] party asserting a claim...may
9 join...as many claims as it has against an opposing party.โ  Whether claims are misjoined is
10 governed by Rule 21 which adverts to Rule 20(a)(1) when determining whether separate persons
11 may join in a single action.  That rule states that such claims may be joined if โ(A) they assert any
12 right to relief jointly, severally, or in the alternative with respect to or arising out of the same
13 transaction, occurrence, or series of transactions or occurrences; and (B) any question of law or
14 fact common to all plaintiffs will arise in the action.โ  These two conditions are in the conjunctive. 
15 Any claims failing to meet these conditions are โmisjoinedโ.  The court finds that the claims in C-
16 08-4255 and C-09-5316 are misjoined.
17 In accordance with Rule 21, the remedy may be the dropping of some of the parties from the
18 complaint or the severance of claims.  The court finds that the better procedure, since these plaintiffs
19 should not all be joining in the same action, is for the court to give plaintiffs in these actions twenty
20 (20) days to drop all but one of the plaintiffs in each of these actions and file new actions as to each
21 of the dropped plaintiffs.  The court will consider the dates of the original filings as being the dates
22 of filings for the new actions.  In other words, the statute of limitations is deemed tolled as of the
23 date of original filing and will continue tolled until the new actions are filed, if they are filed within
24 the twenty days or, if extended by the court, within the extended time.
25 //
26 //
27 //
28 //
3

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document112   Filed03/04/10   Page4 of 4
1 In the future, counsel for plaintiffs are instructed that any new actions shall comply with the
2 preceding paragraphs.  The court will not allow the joining of claims that do not meet the provisions
3 of Rule 20(a)(1).
4 THE FOREGOING IS SO ORDERED.
5
6 Dated: March 3, 2010 _________________________
MARILYN HALL PATEL

~  18  On September 30, 2003, at approximately 11 :30 p.m., defendant Bergeron pulled plaintiff

23  turned from 29th Street onto West Street.  Id., Exh. B (Bergeron Dep.) at 24.  According to

1  II.  The 1998 OPD Strip Search Policy 
2  At the time of the incident, Bergeron did not believe the type of search he performed on 
3  Young was a "strip search." Id. at 43, 48.  At that time, OPD had a policy in place entitled "The 
4  Legal Aspects of Searching Persons."  This policy had been in place since 1998.  Haddad Dec., 
5  Exh. D (1998 Policy) at 1.  It defined a strip search as "any search that requires the officer to remove 
6  or arrange some or all ofa person's clothing to permit a visual inspection of the subject's 
7  underclothing, breasts, buttocks, or genitals." Id. at 8.  The policy further instructed, 
8  A strip search or visual body-cavity search may be conducted only if all of the 
following conditions are met: 
9  โข  The person to be searched must be under arrest and ultimately booked. 
โข  The arrest must be for an offense involving weapons, controlled substances, or 
10  violence. 
...  โข  The person conducting the search must be of the same sex as the person 
11  searched . 
J,.o

u.0=.=.     "'ยง"   12  persons not participating in the search. 
;.g,  
.-
.(..j   u  13  Id.  Bergeron admits the he was required to be knowledgeable of all official policies of the OPD. 
.J-,.o  '0- 
I:I.l  "'Uยง   14  Bergeron Dec. at 7-8.  He also specifically admits that he was required to be knowledgeable of the

".'.C.   -'5"  
.<-1#  15 
[..l...  17  Plaintiffs Foster and Duarte filed the present action on August 1, 2005.  Pursuant to 
= 
;;;;J 
18  stipulations, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on September 22,2005, adding plaintiff Young. 
19  On March 27, 2008, the court partially granted and partially denied plaintiffs' partial motion for 
20  summary judgment.  Docket No. 71 ("March 2008 Order").  Plaintiffs moved for partial summary 
21  judgment on the following grounds: declaratory relief that the OPD's 1998 strip search policy was 
22  unconstitutional; declaratory relief that the 2004 amended policy was unconstitutional; judgment that 
23  any search in accordance with either of the policies was unconstitutional; and summary judgment on 
24  the issue of liability in favor of plaintiffs.  The court held the 1998 policy to be unconstitutional 
25  insofar as it allowed physical body cavity searches to be performed by someone other than a medical 
26  professional.  Id. at 18.  The 2004 policy was found to be unconstitutional to the extent it allowed 
27  strip searches of any kind to be performed in the field on less than probable cause.  Id. at 19.  The 
28 
6 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document99   Filed12/14/09   Page7 of 18
1  other parts of plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment were denied.  Plaintiff Young thereafter filed 
2  the instant motion. 
3 
4  LEGAL STANDARD 
5  Summary judgment may be granted only when, drawing all inferences and resolving all 
6  doubts in favor of the non-moving party, there are no genuine issues of material fact and the moving 
7  party is entitled to judgment as a matter oflaw.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c); see generally Anderson v. 
8  Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242,247-255 (1986).  A fact is "material" ifit may affect the outcome 
9  of the proceedings, and an issue of material fact is "genuine" if the evidence is such that a reasonable 
lO  jury could return a verdict for the non-moving party.  !d. at 248.  The court may not make credibility 
... 
11  determinations.  Id. at 255.  The moving party bears the burden of identifying those portions of the 
1=.   
U.Q..    <'8"   12  pleadings, discovery and affidavits that demonstrate the absence of a genuine issue of material fact. 
..e 
.... 
.~..  ~  13  Celotex Corp. v.  Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323 (1986).  Once the moving party meets its initial burden, 
V 
1.  '-
.- 0 
!;Il 
<~  14  the non-moving party must go beyond the pleadings and, by its own affidavits or discovery, set forth 
Q 
...  6 
!;Il  e 
.~..   15  specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.  Fed R. Civ. P. 56(e); see Anderson, 477 
= ..'l:):  
t:: 
:z0:  
00  16  U.S. at 250. 
".C..   :'.5l.).   
.-~  .0..   17 
= 
~  18  DISCUSSION 
19  Plaintiff Young seeks summary judgment on his claim that defendant Bergeron violated his 
20  Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure.  Young focuses his 
21  arguments on three actions taken by Bergeron: (1) the initial stop of Young on the basis of California 
22  Vehicle Code subsection 26708( a)(2); (2) the arrest of Young on the suspicion he possessed 
23  marijuana; and (3) the alleged strip search ofYoung.2  Bergeron argues that his actions were lawful 
24  and that he is, in any event, protected from liability by the doctrine of qualified immunity. 
25  1.  The Investigatory Stop 
26  Young argues that Bergeron unlawfully stopped his vehicle on the basis of an alleged 
27  violation of California Vehicle Code 26708(a)(2) ("subsection (a)(2)").  "Under the Fourth 
28  Amendment, government officials may conduct an investigatory stop of a vehicle only if they 
7 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document99   Filed12/14/09   Page8 of 18
1  possess reasonable suspicion: a particularized and objective basis for suspecting the particular person 
2  stopped of criminal activity.  Such reasonable suspicion requires specific, articulable facts which, 
3  together with objective and reasonable inferences, form a basis for suspecting that a particular person 
4  is engaged in criminal conduct."  United States v. Twilley, 222 F.3d 1092, 1095 (9th Cir. 2000) 
5  (citations and internal quotation marks omitted). 
6  On February 27,2003, approximately seven months before the incident at issue on this 
7  motion, the California Court of Appeal held a vehicle stop based on the same vehicle code provision 
8  and the same type of air freshener as Young's to have been umeasonable.  People v.  White, 107 Cal. 
9  App. 4th 636 (2003).  In that case, a patrol officer stopped a car with a tree-shaped air freshener 
10  hanging from the rearview mirror.3  Id. at 640-641.  Upon making contact with the driver of the 
...... 
11  vehicle, the officer smelled marijuana and subsequently discovered over five pounds of marijuana 
='""   
u0   O'"s   12  and other contraband.  An occupant of the vehicle, White, was convicted oftransporting marijuana in 
......  <8 
.- :.a 
~ u  13  violation of California law.  He appealed the trial court judge's denial of his suppression motion.  Id. 
..-'."..".   '0- 
.f I.l 
.~  14  at 639-640 . 
t; 
~ 
is 
fI.l  E  15  The Court of Appeal reversed the lower court, holding that reasonable suspicion was lacking. 
..~....  -u=  
..e..o.:.   t:: 
rJ1  z0   16  The court found that subsection (a)(2) does not flatly prohibit hanging any object from a rearview 
u 
'"0  -.5..  
...~.-...   u0. .  17  mirror.  Rather, subsection (a)(2) proscribes the placement of articles in or upon the vehicle which 
= 
~  18  "obstruct or reduce the driver's clear view through the windshield or side windows."  See Cal. Veh. 
19  Code ยง 26708(a)(2).  The officer never testified that he believed the air freshener obstructed the 
20  driver's view.  He also did not testify to specific and articulable facts, like erratic driving, that might 
21  suggest the driver's view was impeded.  Moreover, an expert had testified that the air freshener 
22  covered less that 0.05 percent of the windshield of the car at issue.  Id. at 642.  The court held, "[o]n 
23  this record," that it was not objectively reasonable to believe the air freshener obstructed or reduced 
24  the driver's clear view through the windshield in violation of the vehicle code.  Id. 
25  Bergeron does not dispute Young's contention that his air freshener was the same 
26  "ubiquitous" air freshener at issue in White.  According to Young, Bergeron should have known at 
27  the time of the incident with Young that a tree-shaped air freshener hanging from a rearview mirror 
28  cannot be the factual basis for a violation of subsection (a)(2).  Young's reading of White is too 
8 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document99   Filed12/14/09   Page9 of 18
1  narrow.4  White rejects a construction of the code section that would flatly prohibit hanging a tree-
2  shaped air freshener from a rearview mirror; however, it does not adopt the position that such an 
3  item can never provide the basis for a stop.  Aside from Bergeron's very general description of the 
4  air freshener, neither party has submitted evidence pertaining to the size of his windshield, the exact 
5  size of the air freshener or any other factor that would shed light on whether the air freshener reduced 
6  Young's view.  While Bergeron admitted he did not see any moving violation, he testified in his 
7  deposition that Young's car looked as if it had been traveling "faster than it should have been for 
8  having to stop at a stop sign." Whether these facts are sufficiently specific and articulable to support 
9  "reasonable suspicion" depends upon the credibility of Bergeron and must be weighed by the finder 
10  of fact rather than decided on summary judgment. 
... 
...  11  II.  The Arrest 
= 
c 
U...   E'"   12  The parties agree that Bergeron placed Young under arrest at the point Bergeron handcuffed 
<2 
...~.-...   'u...i.    13  Young while Young sat in the driver's seat of his car.  See Bergeron Depo. at 29.  While it is not 
- 0 
.r IJ  t}  14  clear whether this was technically an arrest, it was a seizure for Fourth Amendment purposes . 
'~ 
~ 
...  Ci 
.~r.I.J    E..,   15  Young contends that Bergeron lacked probable cause.  The Fourth Amendment requires that a law 
" โฌ
~ 
z0  
rJJ  16  enforcement officer have "probable cause" to arrest an individual without a warrant.  United States v. 
"..0.   ..'".;.   
..~..  ::0... .  17  Jensen, 425 F.3d 698, 704 (9th Cir. 2005), cert. denied, 126 S.Ct. 1664.  "The test for whether 
= 
~  18  probable cause exists is whether 'at the moment of arrest the facts and circumstances within the 
19  knowledge of the arresting officers and of which they had reasonably trustworthy information were 
20  sufficient to warrant a prudent man in believing that the petitioner had committed or was committing 
21  an offense.'"  Id. (quoting United States v. Bernard, 623 F.2d 551, 559 (9th Cir. 1980). "A 
22  determination as to whether probable cause exists requires a practical, common-sense decision based 
23  on the totality ofthe circumstances, including the veracity, basis of knowledge and reliability of the 
24  information provided by informants." ld. (internal quotation marks omitted) (citing Illinois v. Gates, 
25  462 US. 213, 214 (1983)).  "Hunches" or "gut feelings" are insufficient to establish reasonable 
26  suspicion, let alone probable cause.  United States v. Johnson, 256 F.3d 895, 905 (9th Cir. 2001) (en 
27  banc). 
28 
9 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document99   Filed12/14/09   Page10 of 18
1  For the purposes of this motion, the court accepts as true Bergeron's testimony that he 
2  smelled a strong scent of fresh marijuana and that he saw crumbs on Young's shirt that looked like 
3  manJuana.  Young objects that Bergeron had no definitive proof that any such crumbs were 
4  manJuana.  He contends that any odor Bergeron smelled, combined with the crumbs, was not enough 
5  to constitute probable cause that Young had committed a crime.  In Young's view, Bergeron merely 
6  had a hunch that Young had large quantities of marijuana. 
7  It must first be noted that Bergeron was not required to have probable cause to suspect Young 
8  had "large quantities" of marijuana, as Young's counsel repeatedly characterizes the inquiry.  A more 
9  proper question is whether Bergeron had probable cause to believe Young had enough marijuana to 
10  violate the law.  A second important question is whether at the time of the arrest Bergeron believed 
...... 
a..  11  he had probable cause to arrest Young for a felony or only a misdemeanor, which is a citable offense

20  The next question is whether the strip search of Young violated his Fourth Amendment right 
21  to be free of unreasonable search and seizure.  The constitutionality ofa search is assessed by 
22  balancing the need for the particular search against the invasion of personal rights that the search 
23  entails.  This requires the court to weigh the scope of the particular intrusion, the manner in which it 
24  is conducted, the justification for initiating it, and the place in which it is conducted.  Way v. County 
25  a/Ventura, 445 F.3d 1157,1160 (9th Cir. 2006) (quoting Bell v.  Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 559 (1979)). 
26  "The test of reasonableness under the Fourth Amendment is not capable of precise definition or 
27  mechanical application.  In each case it requires a balancing of the need for the particular search 
28  against the invasion of personal rights that the search entails." Bell, 441 U.S. at 559. 
13 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document99   Filed12/14/09   Page14 of 18
1  Based on a detailed review of the case law concerning strip searches and body cavity 
2  searches, this court articulated Fourth Amendment requirements for strip searches in the field, in the 
3  context of determining whether a given police department policy is constitutional.  Because the 
4  Fourth Amendment test is not a bright line rule, this list is non-exhaustive when applied to questions 
5  of liability arising out of particular incidents; other factors must be considered as appropriate to the 
6  individual circumstances.  In order to justify a strip search in the field: (1) there must be exigent 
7  circumstances; (2) the search may only be performed on persons who have been lawfully arrested on 
8  probable cause and may not be performed on anyone for whom there is no probable cause to arrest; 
9  (3) the search requires probable cause that is independent of the probable cause found for the arrest; 
10  and (4) the search may only be performed when there is probable cause to believe that the arrestee is

10  IV.  Qualified Immunity 
..

11  Even if a law enforcement officer violates an individual's constitutional rights, the officer 
= 
0  '"  12  may be protected by the doctrine of qualified immunity.  Qualified immunity shields a public official 
U  E 
......   .s 
... 
ii 
..~..  u  13  from individual liability for civil damages under 42 US.C. section 1983 so long as his conduct does 
...  "'"'

r.Il  .~  14  not "violate clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person would 
!:l

Qj  E...   15  have known." Harlow v. Fitzgerald, 457 US. 800, 818 (1982).  "Qualified immunity balances two 
....  ' โฌ
~ 
0 
00  Z  16  important interests~-the need to hold public officials accountable when they exercise power 
'" 
"....'.0..    -.5...  
Qj  u0.   17  irresponsibly and the need to shield officials from harassment, distraction, and liability when they 
= 
~  18  perform their duties reasonably.  The protection of qualified immunity applies regardless of whether 
19  the government official's error is a mistake of law, a mistake of fact, or a mistake based on mixed 
20  questions of law and fact."  Pearson v. Callahan, _  U.S. _, _, 129 S.Ct. 808, 815 (2009) 
21  (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).  Qualified immunity "provides ample protection to 
22  all but the plainly incompetent or those who knowingly violate the law." Malley v. Briggs, 475 US. 
23  335,341 (1986).  As qualified immunity provides immunity from suit and is not merely a defense to 
24  liability, it is important to "resolv[ e] immunity questions at the earliest possible stage in litigation." 
25  See Hunter v. Blyant, 502 U.S. 224,227 (1991). 
26  In Saucier v. Katz, 533 US. 194 (2001), the Supreme Court articulated an inquiry for 
27  determining whether qualified immunity is appropriate.  For an official to benefit from qualified 
28  immunity, two requirements must be met.  First, the court must determine whether, taken in the light 
15 

Case3:05-cv-03110-SI   Document99   Filed12/14/09   Page16 of 18
1  most favorable to the party asserting the injury, the facts alleged show the officer's conduct violated 
2  a constitutional right.  Id. at 201.  Second, the court must consider whether any constitutional right 
3  that was violated was so clearly established that a reasonable officer would understand that what he 
4  is doing violates that right.  Id. at 202.  The second inquiry is particularized, as it occurs in the 
5  specific context of the situation confronted by the official.  Id.; see also Rudebusch v. Hughes, 313 
6  F.3d 506, 514 (9th Cif. 2002).  The Saucier inquiry articulated the first question as a threshold 
7  question; however the Court recently held that lower courts may "exercise their sound discretion in 
8  deciding which of the two prongs of the qualified immunity analysis should be addressed first in 
9  light of the circumstances in the particular case at hand." Pearson, 129 S.Ct. at 818.

23 LEGAL STANDARD
24 A class may be certified in a case that meets the four prerequisites enumerated in Rule 23(a)
25 and at least one of the requirements of Rule 23(b).  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23.  Under Rule 23(a), the party
26 seeking class certification must establish numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy of
27 representation.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a).  In addition to the explicit requirements set out by Rule 23(a),
28
5

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document79    Filed01/13/09   Page6 of 12
1 the class definition must set forth a class which is adequately defined and clearly ascertainable.  See
2 DeBremaecker v. Short, 433 F.2d 733, 734 (5th Cir. 1970).  
3 The party seeking class certification bears the burden of establishing that the requirements of
4 Rule 23(a) and (b) have been met.  Zinser v. Accufix Research Inst., 253 F.3d 1180, 1186 (9th Cir.
5 2001), amended by 273 F.3d 1266 (9th Cir. 2001); Hanon v. Dataproducts Corp., 976 F.2d 497, 508
6 (9th Cir. 1992).  When adjudicating a motion for class certification, the court accepts the allegations
7 in the complaint as true so long as those allegations are sufficiently specific to permit an informed
8 assessment as to whether the requirements of Rule 23 have been satisfied.  Blackie v. Barrack, 524
9 F.2d 891, 901 (9th Cir. 1975).  The merits of the class membersโ substantive claims are generally
10 irrelevant to this inquiry.  Eisen v. Carlisle & Jacquelin, 417 U.S. 156, 177-78 (1974); see also
t 11 Moore v. Hughes Helicopters, Inc., 708 F.2d 475, 480 (9th Cir. 1983).

i
n

18 When plaintiffs brought their first motion to certify, their proposed class did not meet the
19 numerosity requirement.  Five additional cases have been filed since that time.  Plaintiffs note that
20 there are now thirty-nine named plaintiffs who would meet the class definition and further assert that
21 there are eleven more persons who have not yet been named.  The numerosity requirement states that
22 a class action is appropriate โonly if the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is
23 impracticable.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a)(1).  Both plaintiffs and defendants, as well as this court, have
24 taken note of one treatiseโs observation that โ[a] class of 41 or more is usually sufficiently
25 numerous.โ  Mooreโs Federal Practice ยง 23.22[1][b]; see January 2007 Order at 8; Mot. at 10; Opp.
26 at 17.  However, there is no magic number.  The number of potential class members needed to
27 establish numerosity varies with other factors, such as geographical dispersion and the difficulty in
28 identifying class members.  See Moeller v. Taco Bell, 220 F.R.D. 604, 608 (N.D. Cal. 2004)
6

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document79    Filed01/13/09   Page7 of 12
1 (Jenkins, J.); Mooreโs Federal Practice ยง 23.22[1][a] (noting that no single factor controls); see also
2 Allen v. Isaac, 99 F.R.D. 45 (N.D. Ill. 1983) (deciding that class of 17 satisfied numerosity
3 requirement); Joshlin v. Gannett River States Publโg Corp., 152 F.R.D. 577, 579 (E.D. Ark. 1993)
4 (deciding that class of 95 failed to satisfy numerosity requirement).
5 Plaintiffs also propose certification of four subclasses.  When appropriate, a class may be
6 divided into subclasses that are each treated as a class.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(5).  Yet each subclass
7 โmust independently meet the requirements of Rule 23 for the maintenance of a class action.โ  Estate
8 of Felts v. Genworth Life Ins. Co., 250 F.R.D. 512 (W.D. Wa. 2008), quoting Betts v. Reliable
9 Collection Agency, Ltd., 659 F.2d 1000, 1005 (9th Cir. 1981).  The court must, then, determine not
10 only whether the numerosity requirement is met for the overall class, but whether each subclass
t 11 meets the requirement.

4 II. Rule 23(b)
5 To be certified, a class definition must meet at least one of Rule 23(b)โs enumerated
6 requirements.  As explained below, none are met in this case.  
7
8 A. Rule 23(b)(1) 
9 A class action may be certified under Rule 23(b)(1) if the prosecution of separate actions
10 would have the effect of establishing incompatible standards of conduct for the opposing party or if
t 11 separate actions would impair individual class membersโ interests.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(1); see
r
u
o a 12 generally Wright & Miller, Civil Practice & Procedure, ยงยง 1773 & 1774.  In this case, there is no
C ni

ct alif 13 danger of either.  By its nature, any standard of conduct set forth for the OPD and its officers will be

Dis strict  14 a standard of general applicability.  The individual right to be free from unlawful strip searches does
  Di
tates orthern  15 not vary from person to person.  Plaintiffs raise the specter of multiple courts issuing conflicting
S N 16 injunctions.  There is no real danger of such occurring in this case.  All incidents at issue have
ted  For the  17 occurred in Oakland, and every action has been filed in the Northern District of California and been

18 related to the others.  Hypothetically, some related claims could be filed in state court, and the state
19 and federal courts could issue conflicting injunctions.  Such a possibility exists regardless of whether
20 or not this action is treated on a class action basis.  There is, in this case, no real danger of
21 establishing incompatible standards of conduct.
22 Neither is there a concern that separate actions would impair individual class membersโ
23 interests.  The individual claims arise from very different individual factual circumstances.  This is
24 not an instance in which the disposition of one plaintiffโs case will in some way impair the ability of
25 other plaintiffs to protect their interests.  Classes are typically certified under Rule 23(b)(1)(B) when
26 a common fund of a limited amount exists to settle claims and the separate adjudication of claims
27 may leave those plaintiffs who later establish a right to payment with no funds left to satisfy that
28 right.  See, e.g., In re Drexel Burnham Group, 960 F.2d 285, 292 (2d Cir. 1992) (certifying class
8

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document79    Filed01/13/09   Page9 of 12
1 where limited amount of funds was available to pay victims).  Cases not involving a common fund
2 but rather some other common interest have been found to merit class treatment in accordance with
3 this rule.  See, e.g., Robertson v. Natโl Basketball Assโn, 556 F.2d 682, 685 (2d Cir. 1977)
4 (certifying class in antitrust suit where preventing merger of two competing basketball leagues
5 would affect interests of all professional basketball players).  A judgment for one plaintiff against
6 the City of Oakland would not affect a different plaintiffโs ability to collect on his own judgment.  
7
8 B.   Rule 23(b)(2)
9 This rule is limited to cases in which โfinal injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory
10 relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2).  Legal remedies
t 11 which are incidental to a request for injunctive relief may be included as a part of the claim.

25 C. Rule 23(b)(3)
26 Class certification pursuant to this rule requires that the court determine โthat the questions
27 of law or fact common to the class members predominate . . .โ and that a class action is โsuperior to
28 other available methodsโ for fairly adjudicating the controversy.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).

1 Plaintiffsโ moving papers observe that blanket strip search cases such as Bull v. City and County of
2 San Francisco, 539 F.3d 1193 (9th Cir. 2008), have been found suitable for class action treatment. 
3 In the blanket strip search cases cited by plaintiffs, the complainants challenged a general policy to
4 strip search in a particular way all individuals meeting certain criteria.  In such a case, a defendantโs
5 liability for violating the law can be determined on a class-wide basis.  Plaintiffs in the related cases
6 at bar challenge individual searches conducted under specific attendant circumstances.  The cases
7 involve individual alleged incidents in different parts of Oakland occurring over the course of
8 several years and involving many different police officers.  Some plaintiffs had outstanding arrest
9 warrants; some did not.  Some of the plaintiffs were on parole or probation; some were not.  The
10 types of strip search allegedly performed on plaintiffs varies widely, from anal body cavity searches
t 11 to the lifting of the waistband or their undergarments.  Determinations of liability cannot be made
r
u
o a 12 without significant inquiry into the attendant facts of each alleged incident.
C ni
  or
ct alif 13 The fact that the alleged strip searches took place at a time when unconstitutional policies
i C
tr of 
Dis strict  14 were in effect is not enough in itself to establish that any particular search was unconstitutional.  As
  Di
tates orthern  15 this court previously noted, the Ninth Circuit has observed that โa search, although not supportable
S N 16 under an institutional policy, is not per se unconstitutional.โ  Kennedy v. Los Angeles Police Dept.,
ted  For the  17 901 F.2d 702, 715 (9th Cir. 1990), abrogated on other grounds by Hunter v. Bryant, 502 U.S. 224
i
n
U
18 (1991); see March 2008 MSJ Order at 20.  There is a factual dispute over whether many or all of the
19 strip searches took place, and a finding that  a particular search took place has no necessary relation
20 to whether any other search took place.  Similarly, a finding that a given search was undertaken, for
21 example, with independent probable cause does not dispose of the question of whether any other
22 given search was or was not conducted with independent probable cause.  Since the test for
23 constitutionality involves several fact-intensive inquiries specific to each incident, common
24 questions plainly do not predominate.  
25 This is not to say that these cases involve no common questions of law or fact.  Once
26 individual cases are brought to trial, it may become apparent that there is a basis for Monell claims
27 against the municipal defendants.  See Monell v. Depโt of Social Services of City of New York, 436
28 U.S. 658, 690 (1978) (holding that a municipality may be subject to section 1983 liability where
10

Case3:05-cv-03110-MHP   Document79    Filed01/13/09   Page11 of 12
1 official policy or custom causes a constitutional tort).  If so, a Monell hearing may be held.  Class
2 certification would not, however, assist with such a determination.   
3
4 CONCLUSION
5 For the foregoing reasons, plaintiffsโ renewed motion for class certification is DENIED.
6
7 IT IS SO ORDERED.

Case: 09-74059     01/13/2010     Page: 1 of 2      DktEntry: 7193808
FILED
UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS JAN 13 2010
MOLLY C. DWYER, CLERK
 FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT U.S. COURT OF APPEALS
In re: WILLIAM BERGERON. No. 09-74059
D.C. No. 3:05-cv-03110-MHP
Northern District of California, 
WILLIAM BERGERON, San Francisco
                    Petitioner,
ORDER
   v.
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF
CALIFORNIA (SAN FRANCISCO),
                    Respondent,
YANCIE YOUNG,
                    Real Party in Interest.
Before:  SILVERMAN, PAEZ and BEA, Circuit Judges.  
Petitioner has not demonstrated that this case warrants the intervention of
this court by means of the extraordinary remedy of mandamus.  See Bauman v.
United States Dist. Court, 557 F.2d 650 (9th Cir. 1977).  The posture of the case
did not require the district judge to rule on qualified immunity.  The district court
ec/MOATT

Case: 09-74059     01/13/2010     Page: 2 of 2      DktEntry: 7193808
had before it only the real party in interestโs motion; there was no cross-motion by
petitioner.  Accordingly, the petition is denied.
In denying the petition for writ of mandamus, we in no way preclude the
petitioner from seeking a ruling by the district court on his affirmative defense of
qualified immunity either by a properly filed motion for summary judgment or at
trial.  
Petitionerโs alternative request to construe this petition as a notice of appeal
of the district courtโs December 14, 2009 order, entered December 15, 2009, and a
motion for stay of district court proceedings is denied.  
BEA, Circuit Judge:
I dissent.  The district court erred in entering partial summary judgment in
favor of real party in interest Young with respect to his 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 claim of
an unconstitutional search without having determined the issue of qualified
immunity, vel non.  See Pearson v. Callahan, 129 S. Ct. 808 (2009); Saucier v.
Katz, 121 S. Ct. 2151 (2001).
ec/MOATT 2 09-74059
